Not sure what list you are referring to that has Jimi #3. I’ve never seen him ranked anything other than #1. The problem with any ranking is that it’s totally subjective. Also, there are many styles of guitar that are never even considered in such lists: classical, Spanish, flamenco, jazz. There are some classical guitar players that literally take your breath away. Thus, Jimi can properly only be described as “the best rock/blues guitarist of all time.” In that light, and with that qualification, were you to arbitrarily put Jimi at #3, you would then bump up #2 and #3 ahead of him. Most lists would give you Clapton at #1 and Page at #2. There are a handful of other guys that would vie for this spots depending on preference. Some people love the “shredders” others the technical guys like Steve Vai. Other people look at who was the most influential, pushed the guitar to new places, had the most innovative sound, etc. No one will agree since different things appeal to different people. But, for argument sake, there was no one like Clapton. Technically flawless, soulful, and moving. Page gave us some of the greatest licks, solos and rhythms in rock history. His brain sometimes got ahead of his fingers and he got sloppy, which is why Clapton is ahead of him. But in the studio, Page was a GOD.
